alert.note: Alert for Yavapai (Arizona) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued May 19 at 4:00PM MST until May 20 at 12:00AM MST by NWS Flagstaff
info.description: The National Weather Service in Flagstaff has issued a * Flash Flood Warning for... Yavapai County in west central Arizona along Black Canyon, Turkey Creek, and Castle Creek... * Until midnight MST Saturday. * At 358 PM MST, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Up to 2 inches of rain have fallen. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly. HAZARD...Life-threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Life-threatening flash flooding of low-water crossings, creeks, normally dry washes and roads. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Crown King, Castle Hot Springs, Rock Springs, Bumble Bee, Lake Pleasant, Black Canyon City, Hazlett Hollow Campground and Turney Gulch Group Campground. This includes the following highways... Interstate 17 between mile markers 242 and 251. This includes the following creeks, washes and rivers... Buckhorn Creek, Boulder Creek, Hamlin Wash, Amazon Gulch, Hassayampa River, Oak Creek, Wolf Creek, Turkey Creek, Castle Creek, Tussock Spring Creek, Black Canyon Creek, Sycamore Creek, Agua Fria River, Little Buckhorn Creek, Black Canyon, Whipsaw Creek, East Fork Castle Creek, Cedar Creek, Antelope Creek, French Creek, Tuscumbia Creek, North Fork Rock Creek, Banty Creek, Cottonwood Creek, Buzzard Roost Creek, Rock Creek, Bear Creek, Ash Creek and Mineral Creek. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: Flooding of washes and creeks will occur, some dirt roads will become muddy and impassable. Paved roads and underpasses could become flooded as well. In hilly or mountainous terrain, there are many low water crossings which will become dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded roads. Find an alternate route.
